neutron/conf/agent/cmd.py.message:
After I read the relevant code I think this still does not describe the actual behavior. To my understanding this is how the code behaves (without implying whether this is the wanted behavior or not):

1) We always act on all ovs bridges - the value of ovs_all_ports does not matter in that. Please see my comment in the bug report.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1853582/comments/4

2) ovs_all_ports=True deletes absolutely all ports on all bridges.

3) ovs_all_ports=False deletes all VIFs on all bridges.

Where vifs are ports (whose interfaces) marked with both external_ids iface-id and attached-mac. (That's what we call vif, right?)

I'm not sure if skip_cleanup needs to be explained in this help string.

Since nova and neutron both create vifs (nova for VMs, neutron for routers, dhcp, etc.), I think the the correct help would be: False to only delete VIFs on all bridges. ;-)

If I had to guess the original intent it would be like:

'No' to clean up all ports except patch ports (and the special bridge representor port with the same name as the bridge). 'Yes' to clean up absolutely everything.

For the record here's one diff of what it actually cleaned up from a random devstack environment:

$ diff -u ~/ports-{before,after}-cleanup
--- /home/rubasov/ports-before-cleanup  2019-12-09 14:38:23.345733351 +0000
+++ /home/rubasov/ports-after-cleanup   2019-12-09 14:36:01.876459607 +0000
@@ -2,18 +2,9 @@
 br-int
 br-physnet0
 br-tun
-fg-1731b198-e0
 int-br-ex
 int-br-physnet0
 patch-int
 patch-tun
 phy-br-ex
 phy-br-physnet0
-qg-abf516cf-90
-qr-1ea78e69-2a
-qr-1f0311dc-64
-sg-2c2ad50e-aa
-sg-ba92a268-ae
-tap2c3402b2-4b
-tap3d587e18-b0
-tapc10c9b62-9f

For (1) see my comments in the bug.
For (2) agree.
For (3) I can change it to "False to only delete VIFs on the integration bridge"

(1) You're right.
(3) As you feel like. My main point wanted to be about the bridges - but I was wrong about that. Writing about VIFs is technically more correct but the concept of a VIF may not be well known to even administrators.

nit: as you never check the contents of exception_to_reraise and raise PlacementResourceProviderGenerationConflict, it should be True or False.

Be careful: we are not throwing "PlacementInventoryUpdateConflict" anymore. [1] will fail now

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/97e495671f5746d7a0e54a7cd67fc5baf7669813/neutron/services/segments/plugin.py#L227

Nice catch. Here's the followup neutron change:

https://review.opendev.org/698261

in fact I now wonder how we can end up with case when reraise == False here and I think that we simply can't.
If _put() in L230 will end up with success we will simply return there and never get to this line. If it will raise conflict all the time than finally we will get here and will always have to raise this exception. There is no other way to miss return from L230 and get here. Am I missing something?
You are right, "reraise" is not necessary. If we reach this line (the code did not return in L230), that means we must raise "PlacementResourceProviderGenerationConflict".

Quote from placement api reference [1]:

  A mismatch indicates that a different request successfully updated that entity in the interim, thereby changing its generation. This will result in an HTTP 409 Conflict response with error code placement.concurrent_update.

Therefore, I would suggest to check the error code as well. We should retry only if the error code is 'placement.concurrent_update'. What do you think?

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/placement/#resource-provider-and-consumer-generations

1) Skip the tests
2) Execute tests based on the provider
3) Discovery

3) seems complicated but perhaps it's the solution we should tend to in the long term so definitely worth to explore.

octavia_tempest_plugin/tests/test_base.p.message: Tempest tests are expected to be provider agnostic.
What is the expected response count from a load balancer on, say, SOURCE_IP_PORT algorithm? Could you please add an assertion for that algorithm too?

Lets consider an example. We have LB with SOURCE_IP_PORT balancing algorithm and 2 members.

SOURCE_IP_PORT algorithm is used and tempest is configured to not reuse connections [0]:
a) With number of 20 HTTP requests we're sure that both members gets hit, we can calculate it: 

1 - (0.5)^20 = 1 - 9.53674316e-7., so we're sure :) (99.99+%)

b) It is very likely that both members haven't the same number of responses

WHY: If there is a new hash in member selector (the port is not being reused, because there is new source port) member is selected randomly from the pool. So, from probabilistic point of view there is a possibility that this code could fail:

self.assertEqual(2, len(set(response_counts.values())))

But it is very unlikely, from what I think it will be around:(0.5)^20, so: 9.53674316e-7 (correct me if I'm wrong).

So I'll add this check:
self.assertEqual(2, len(set(response_counts.values())))


[0] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672976/

Unfortunately this check sometime is True, sometime is False. As per my previous comment around this code - members are randomly selected when there is no hash that identifies previous packets. So we base on possibilities here, and we cannot guarantee that number of responses will be equal or not for all the members during all the runs.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Was just starting to test out this feature on my devstack, of course at the first go I just ran this with the default "NOBODY" policy so it defaulted to traditional resize and started searching in the same cell and returned a "ComputeHostNotFound" error which was confusing because what I expected was a "your policy does not allow you to perform this action" error. Later I read this commit message and realized that its designed to fall into the traditional one. I am not sure which is better though, I would prefer to not have nova silently ignore the problem and do what it thinks is right. However the logs are explicitly stating a "Policy check for compute:servers:resize:cross_cell failed with credentials" so as far as debugging goes it was easy to spot this so should be okay for the admins. Although yea, before opening it to users we might have to fix the "ComputeHostNotFound" error since they won't know the concept of cells.

cgcs-patch/cgcs-patch/cgcs_patch/patch_f.message: Does the version you are replacing raise an exception? I don't see the calling functions catching this - what happens if someone attempts to upload a patch with a bad version string?

It's a case that really shouldn't happen. This isn't some freeform string. This is the RPM version, so I'm not sure how it would end up malformed. And the way this regex is written, the only string it won't match is an empty string.

And if it happens, it will get kicked up to the top-level exception handler, which would log the exception.

But I can certainly add a "try" block around the couple of cases that call it, and skip past such bad pkgs.

If somehow some corruption has occurred, such that some package is being reported by RPM with an empty string for its package version, it's not likely to be in a user-triggered case. The agent and/or controller will not be happy and the user will need to look at logs to see this exception there.
I don't want you to add extra code to ignore the bad packages. I just wanted to make sure that there is a reasonable error show to the user if this ever happened.

So this actually updates instance.pci_requests and saves the changes to the DB per host that we try.

What happens if we eventually can't find any suitable host due to all of the pre-checks failing and the task raising MaxRetriesExceeded? Shouldn't we save off the instance.pci_requests early in the task and on rollback set them back onto the instance? Otherwise we could have a modified instance with updated pci_requests for a dest host it never moved it, right?

I remember from the code review on moving that refactored method to compute.utils that Dan suggested we move the actual instance.save() from that method to the caller so it has context and can determine if the instance should be updated, which it easily can do with something like this:

if instance.obj_what_changed():
    instance.save()

Point being that could be useful here because we could opt to only save the changes to the instance once we've selected a host and will exit this method. But regardless of that it's probably worthwhile to just save off the instance.pci_requests early in the task and re-apply them on rollback in case they happened to change during host selection.

Rather than unit tests maybe functional tests for testing rollback would be cleaner? In general the unit tests on these conductor tasks are generally terrible because there is so much content crammed into each method (they really need to be broken down for unit testability) and that results in unit tests have more mocks than the actual code they are trying to test. That's why I've generally just relied on functional testing for stuff like this in recent years than trying to unit test everything because it's hard to say if the test is even working properly or if we have false positives due to mocks.

nova/network/neutronv2/api.py.message: And this is called from migrate_instance_finish.

Is there any reason to not do that in conductor and just let this code update the dest host port binding? I guess the reason is that if we did that, then the provider mapping has to get from conductor (or be built in compute?) to here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d052e72040258b6ab91f53b43e8d45b330b898e1/nova/compute/manager.py#L8511

But isn't that what we do during resize?

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d052e72040258b6ab91f53b43e8d45b330b898e1/nova/compute/manager.py#L5706

I guess resize is done that way since it doesn't use multiple port bindings like live migration does.

So I guess two things:

1. If we are going to leave this code and let conductor update the dest host port binding profile, then shouldn't we remove the TODO at https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d052e72040258b6ab91f53b43e8d45b330b898e1/nova/compute/manager.py#L8511 ?

2. Is there a reason we can't make the compute manager code consistent with respect to when the dest host port binding profile gets updated so that we are consistent between live and cold migrate? Otherwise it's kind of weird to be doing it different ways and have this special case live-migration-only condition down in the bowels of the neutron API code.

I'm -1 for other smaller reasons on this patch, but this is something worth thinking through for long-term maintainability.
So tl;dr using multiple port bindings is the future so we want live migration to continue using that way rather than regress to how resize works today. I can buy that.

Done.

 > 
 > 2. Is there a reason we can't make the compute manager code
 > consistent with respect to when the dest host port binding profile
 > gets updated so that we are consistent between live and cold
 > migrate? Otherwise it's kind of weird to be doing it different ways
 > and have this special case live-migration-only condition down in
 > the bowels of the neutron API code.

To avoid the recalculation of the mapping in case of revert resize we anyhow need to change the resize code path to use multiple port binding. That way the conductor can set the binding both for cold and for live migration. This could remove the difference between the two cases here and solve the revert resize problem at the same time.

As a secondary reason. From the start we planned to use the multiple binding to hold the source allocation key in the source binding in live migration case so I did not add the request_spec to the post_live_migration_at_destination when the RPC was bumped for the qos move operations. So now it would need another RPC bump to pass down the request spec.

 > 
 > I'm -1 for other smaller reasons on this patch, but this is
 > something worth thinking through for long-term maintainability.

OpenStack code style is pedantic about following rule: please import suff using below way.

 from tobiko import podman

Then use podnman things like below:

 podman.get_podman_client(...)

get_podman_client should return an PodmanClientFixture instance. Therefore this should be:
 client = get_podman_client(base_url="unix:@podmantests").connect()

The reason is it is often convenient to encapsulate initialisation parameters in one object without actually initialising it before it is actually required. Lazy initialisation has many advantages especially for heavy resources like system ones.
